awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Using machine learning methods and polymer data to predict properties of new polymers and accelerate application-specific polymer design
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software tool for polymer selection, design and discovery. Potential customers of this technology include polymer chemists or materials designers in companies that manufacture or utilize polymers in industries such as auto, chemicals, and oil and gas.  The value of this technology lies in overcoming the traditional, laborious and expensive trial-and-error approaches to materials development. The total R&D expenditure of the polymer manufacturing industry is about $10 billion per year. This technology has the potential to save an estimated savings of $100 million per year.  In addition, the acceleration of product design workflows could dramatically shorten time-to-market for products that must undergo evolutionary changes throughout the product’s life-cycle.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a data-driven machine learning tool to achieve accelerated application-specific polymer design and development. Machine learning (ML) algorithms trained on an underlying database produce predictive models, which can 1) make instantaneous predictions of properties of a new yet-to-be-synthesized polymer, and 2) make recommendations of new and existing polymers that will meet design objectives. The goal is to create a customized application-specific polymer design tool for end-user companies, and a generic data-to-model product line that ingests in-house proprietary (legacy/historic) polymer data to produce predictive models for polymer manufacturing companies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Over the years, the Ramprasad Group at Georgia Tech has developed IP and innovations in Polymer Informatics, that can accelerate the development, design and optimization of polymers and formulations for a variety of applications. Our NSF I-Corps team sought to determine the market value of our technology, including the identification of target customer segments, validation and quantification of the value proposition, and the determination of product-market fit for data-driven machine learning based polymer property prediction and polymer design software. To gain insights into these three criteria, our team conducted over 100 customer discovery interviews within the US and overseas with professionals working at various points in the value chain of polymer products.

Three major customer segments emerged from these efforts: polymer synthesizers, formulators, and product developers. Synthesizers are scientists involved in creating novel polymer structures on a day-to-day basis. Example companies under this category would be Solvay Specialty Polymers, SABIC, Dow. Formulators are generally involved in taking existing polymers and chemicals, mixing, and reacting them in new ratios that create materials with unique properties. Example companies our team talked to were Henkel, Bosch, Proctor & Gamble. Lastly, product developers are individuals that purchase existing polymer products for applications in assembled goods. Example companies that fall in this category include Apple, Kimberly-Clark, Toyota. The team achieved the hundred interview target mark by attending three different trade shows (including Specialty Chemical America in Fort Worth, the Polyolefins Trade show in Houston, and the advance electronics manufacturing tradeshow in San Diego). In addition, trips were taken to Los Angeles and San Jose area within the US, as well as to UK, Germany, and South Korea to interview relevant companies. Some of the most recognizable companies that participated in the customer discovery process include Tesla/Space-X, Apple, Solvay Specialty Polymers, ExxonMobil, BASF, Henkel, Northrop Grumman, and Kimberly-Clark Corporation.

Several critical and tangible outcomes have emerged from our effort, thanks to the NSF I-Corps program. One of them is the segmentation of the market such that companies within a given segment have common goals and pain points. A couple of examples of segments include polymers/plastics for packaging, and polymers for electronics & electrical applications (devices, batteries, fuel cells). Likewise, on the Technology Development side, we have learned that, while there is general excitement in using ML methods to accelerate materials development, clients are at different stages of readiness. The common problem is that in-house datasets are in various levels of cleanliness and organization. Data curation and data analysis are thus bottlenecks that client companies need assistance with. In addition, most client companies go beyond polymer chemistry in their development work; process and environmental conditions are critical and must be inserted into the ML pipeline.

Perhaps the most tangible outcome of this effort is the formation of the startup company, Matmerize, Inc., (https://www.matmerize.com) based on the lessons learned from this I-Corps program. Matmerize is actively engaging with several clients, and has created a cloud-based materials design software, called PolymRize?. This cloud-based machine learning software can be securely accessed by polymer and formulations chemists via a web browser. It utilizes Matmerize-proprietary or client-proprietary data to build models that can instantly predict the properties and aids in the rapid design of new yet-to-be-synthesized polymers and formulations. Matmerize seeks to define the new industry standard for cost-effective accelerated polymer materials and formulation development by eliminating expensive and long trial-and-error cycles. Companies are beginning to realize the value and opportunity presented by leveraging materials data. Matmerize seeks to take the logical next, but a transformative, step ? leveraging the data to extract knowledge and guide the next experiments toward cost-effective and intelligent materials design.


Last Modified: 01/08/2023
Modified by: Ramamurthy Ramprasad
